resources.string: OONI Probe is free and open source software that enables you to examine internet censorship in your network.
The data that you can collect through this app can serve as evidence of censorship events.
OONI data is openly published and will include your network information.
Anyone monitoring your internet activity (e.g governments or ISP) will know that you are running OONI Probe.
Read the docs to learn more.
Anyone monitoring your internet activity may be able to see that you are running OONI Probe.
My measurements will get published by OONI and they will include my network information.
Anyone monitoring your internet activity (e.g government, ISP, employer) will know that you are running OONI Probe, just like any other software.
This test examines whether access to websites is blocked through DNS tampering, TCP/IP blocking, or by a transparent HTTP proxy.\n\nEvery time you run Web Connectivity you test different websites.

This test tries to detect systems (“middle boxes”) that could be responsible for censorship or surveillance by sending an invalid HTTP request line to an echo service. If such systems are in your network, the invalid HTTP request line will be intercepted and may trigger an error.

This test tries to detect the presence of systems (“middle boxes”) that could be responsible for censorship or surveillance by sending HTTP requests with non-canonical headers to a backend control server. If such systems are in your network, they will likely normalize the headers or add extra headers.

This test measures the speed and performance of your network.\n\nDisclaimer: This is a third-party performance test based on third-party servers, and we cannot guarantee that your IP address will not be collected, processed, and published.

This test emulates a very simple video player streaming at variable quality from a remote server. The test is designed to obtain a baseline performance of your network for performing video streaming.\n\nDisclaimer: This is a third-party performance test based on third-party servers, and we cannot guarantee that your IP address will not be collected, processed, and published.
A little bit more reading is required for you to proceed.
Good job! You have answered the quiz correctly.
All measurements are sent by default to OONI\'s measurement collector and automately published through the OONI explorer and OONI\'s list of measurements.
Successfully configured ooniprobe. You are all set to go!
The Open Observatory of Network Interference (OONI) is a free software project under The Tor Project that aims to increase transparency of internet censorship around the world.
Since 2012, OONI has collected millions of network measurements from around the world, shedding light on multiple instances of internet censorship and traffic manipulation.
The test has no results or it was aborted
Click here to view our data policy
finished, go to Past Tests to see the results
Do you want to open the following URL?
The max runtime you have entered is too low, setting to default.
Do you want to delete all test results?
Past test results will appear here once the tests have finished running
You are about to run an ooniprobe test on your network
In order to run this test you need a newer version of ooniprobe, click on the button below to update
A random sampling of URLs from the global list
ooniprobe is free and open source software that enables you to examine internet censorship in your network!
By running this app, you can examine whether and how websites are blocked, and whether censorship and/or surveillance systems are present in your network.
You can also run this app to measure the speed and performance of your network.
The data that you can collect through this app can serve as evidence of censorship events .
Since ooniprobe is an investigatory tool and as such, may pose some risks.
Anyone monitoring your internet activity (e.g. ISP, government, employer) can know that you are running ooniprobe (even though OONI tries to make this hard).
When testing websites for censorship, you will connect to and download data from provocative or objectionable sites (e.g. pornography) that might be illegal in your country.
OONI’s HTTP invalid request line test might trigger the suspicion of your ISP and could be viewed as a form of “hacking”.

Unless you configure your settings otherwise, all data collected from your tests will by default be published by OONI and might include some personally- identifiable information (though OONI tries to prevent this from happening).
The mere use of ooniprobe might be viewed as a form of espionage, regardless of the laws in your country.

To our knowledge, no ooniprobe user has ever faced consequences from the use of our platform. However, many countries have a lengthy history of targeting and abusing digital rights activists, which could leave ooniprobe users subject to severe civil, criminal, or extra-judicial penalties.
